1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Del Monte Fresh has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 Del Monte Fresh, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Del Monte Fresh has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name                | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Ammonia Refrigeration         Anhydrous Ammonia                16,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RM

P obligations as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Description

The Bin Rooms, Cold Storage Rooms, CA Rooms, and Finished Product Room are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation. The Low Care Production and High Care Production Rooms are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and a pumped recirculator as required for pumped overfeed operation. The Hallways and Loading Dock are equipped with air-cooling evaporators as required for direct expansion (DX) operation.

Del Monte Fresh Produce operates using a combination of flooded, pumped overfeed, and direct expansion system configuration.

The flooded system operates as follows: high press

ure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator. From the accumulators, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulators. The suction gas is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to the main suction accumulator. From the main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.

The pumped overfeed system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped through a series of liquid feed solenoid valves, an expansion valve, and into a liquid recirculator. From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into evaporator. Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculator. The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the gas is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver. 

The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds t

heir set point. 

There is one emergency control box installed in Del Monte Fresh Produce. It is located on the south exterior wall of the refrigeration machinery room, and contains three valves, and the emergency refrigeration switch. The high and low side of the system each have a valve that would discharge to atmosphere. The connecting pipe between the high and low side has one equalizer valve that would equalize the system.

The ammonia refrigeration system at Del Monte Fresh Produce consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Del Monte Fresh Produce is treated as a single process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Del Monte Fresh has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Del Monte Fresh facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 16,000 LBS. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is check

ed frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

Del Monte Fresh has had one (1) accident within the last five (5) years.
Incident Investigation # 2016-­02
Date of incident: December 15, 2016
Time accident began: 5:47 PM
NAICS: 115114
Accident duration: 16 hours
Regulated substance released: Anhydrous Ammonia
Estimated quantity released: 24,000 lbs.
Release event: Gas release & Liquid spills/evaporation
Source: Anhydrous Ammonia release through broken piping
Weather conditions: 
Wind speed and direction: 9.2 mph SSE
Temperature: 55 degrees F 
Atmospheric stability class: D
Precipitation present: Raining
Onsite impacts: Property Damage, no injuries or deaths
Offsite impacts: Sheltered in place (total unknown), no injuries or deaths
Initiating event and contributing factors:
During a heavy rainstorm, the roof over the Finish Product Room collapsed. Two (2) ceiling­-suspended evaporative coils fell with the roof, breaking the piping between the roof mounted accumulator and the two (2) coils. Upon inspection, the wooden roof supports displayed water damage which led to rot and weakened the beams.
Offsite responders notified and responded
Recommendations:
The ceiling­-suspending evaporative coils, accumulator and piping was severely damaged during the 12/15/16 roof collapse. Ensure to isolate, safely remove and repair process equipment in accordance with IIAR standards. Additionally, ensure that Management of Change/Pre-­Startup Safety Review documentation is completed in accordance with RMP/PSM/CalARP regulations.
Ensure to have a structural engineer evaluate the entire roof to determine if structurally sound and safe to re­occupy facility. Repair all sections of roof and supporting structure which are inadequate.
Del Monte Fresh employees evacuated in a safe and timely man

ner, with no reportable injuries. However, Del Monte management could not provide relevant site maps and piping and instrumentation diagrams to emergency responders. Maps and P&IDs were brought onsite by consultants nearly four hours after the roof collapse. Complete emergency response training with designated Del Monte Fresh employees. Ensure to emphasize assessing emergency situations, notifications and contractor support.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Del Monte Fresh's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR §3220
- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR §1910.38
- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR §5189(n)
- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR §1910.119(n)
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 §2765.1-2765.2
- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR §68.95
- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 §2731
- California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 §5192(q)
- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR §1910.120(q)

Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, includ

ing a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Del Monte Fresh has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Del Monte Fresh continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.
By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Del Monte Fresh's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Del Monte Fresh's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Del Monte Fresh has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Del Monte Fresh has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.
For the future, Del Monte Fresh now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Del Monte Fresh employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Del Monte Fresh will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
